This is a new reprap.xml file for ReplicatorG that allows you to use your reprap or other Sprinter-based firmware machine with ReplicatorG. This version supports extruder control from the control panel. If there is a machine that you would like to have a driver for I will update the .xml file with a driver to suit your needs. Tested Electronics
  • RAMPS
  • Sanguinololu
    • Tested Firmwares
  • Sprinter
  • Marlin

• Download
  • Open ReplicatorG folder.
  • Open machines folder.
  • Replace reprap.xml with this new one.
  • Restart ReplicatorG.
  • Select the Machine tab.
  • Under Driver select your machine.
  • Print!
  • Celebrate!

Wow, this works. I'm honestly really surprised. I changed the code to fix it for me (https://github.com/makerbot/ReplicatorG/commit/bce0c694f5677c63682ef6a9932b1e54958671dc)https://github.com/makerbot/Re... but this fixes it too and seems much simpler. What was your fix? I see no stepper_axis var in the new Prusa Mendel machine definition; was that is? Inquiring minds want to know!
comments.author: Pointedstick

comments.text: Well what was happening is that previous versions were trying to determine the extruder as an axis. Which is how the Thing-O-Matic does. By doing this RepG looks for settings for that axis. When it can't find the settings it basically "forgets" about the extruder motor. By identifying it as part of the extruder and telling RepG that it is a stepper extruder it allows separate parameters to be set in the tool parameters.

description.text:
This is a library that allows for easy creation of screw throughholes, screws and easy documentation of materials.
It allows to directly use the name of the screw/nut size you want to work with. No more looking up screw sizes, while clearances can still be set via parameters. Look in the code, there is extensive documentation on the available parameters. Btw: Visit my github project for the latest version: https://github.com/JohK/nutsnbolts If you are more interested in printing the actual screws/nuts and a more visually appealing representation of the screws, have a look at stth's openscad code thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:269863

include <cyl_head_bolt.scad>; difference() { translate([-15, -15, 0]) cube([80, 30, 50]); rotate([180,0,0]) nutcatch_parallel("M5", l=5); translate([0, 0, 50]) hole_through(name="M5", l=50+5, cl=0.1, h=10, hcl=0.4); translate([55, 0, 9]) nutcatch_sidecut("M8", l=100, clk=0.1, clh=0.1, clsl=0.1); } screw("M20x100", thread="modeled"); // screw M20x100 with thread nut("M20", thread="modeled"); // corresponding nut with thread screw("M3x12"); // screw M3x12

comments.text: Thank you so much for this! Can we generate some American screws like the 10-32  x  1/4 ? Is any way?
comments.author: madarakis

comments.text:
The library is actually designed with the extension to other standards in mind.
Have a look at the "data-metric_cyl_head_bolt.scad" file, which basically is the database for the generation of the screws and screwcatches. If someone compiles the corresponding database for UNC screws the lib can be used with those as well. Everything apart from the thread-modelling should then work right away (afaik the lead is defined differently in ISO and UNC screws).
comments.author: madarakis

title: V-Slot Openbuilds Mini Gantry Direct Drive Extruder mount

description.text:
This is a mount designed to run a Direct Drive Extruder on the Openbuilds Mini Gantry. Install QTY (4) 3mm nuts in the cavities provided in the Direct Drive Mount (DDM). Bolt the DDM the Gantry using the provide Gantry mounting screws Attached the NEMA 17 Motor to the Motor Mount (MM) using 3mm screws (30-35-40mm depending on mount and motor choice) through the back of the mount into the motor frame. Edit:
Added V-2 of the NEMA mount, it is a thicker version to allow a full length screw to be used. I would suggest printing both and using the one that provides the best if. Attach the MM to the DDM using 3mm screws. Thanks to Jason (therippa) for the original concept. You can check out his other designs and follow him here: http://www.thingiverse.com/therippa/about Note: As I run a Bowden Extruder this mount has not be printed or tested...

comments.text: On these direct drive mounts the prox sensor is usually mounted on/with the extruder. Which extruder and hotend combo you decide to use will drive the location of the mount (height). Similar to this one:
comments.author: sonnylowe

comments.text: I believe the two normal sensors are 12mm and 18mm, I have both so it's no big deal either way. I'm planning on running your v-slot gantry, direct drive with the e3d titan and v6. The v6 mounts directly in the titan, so unfortunately I have to come up with another way to mount a sensor. Openbuilds hasn't started shipping their mini gantry yet, hopefully tomorrow. Thanks!

A long time back, when I was first learning to code in Windows, I rand the Charles Petzold digital clock application as a sample. Since then, I've done everything with that clock from rendering in OpenGL to high resolution timers. This thing takes the seven segment digital display and renders it in OpenScad. It's pretty straight forward. There are three routines.
DisplayDigit(number, height) - Will display a single digit, centered at the origin. DisplayDigits(numbers, count, height) - Will display a sequence of numbers, separated by a gap of 4mm. RenderDigitsPlate(digits, count, thickness, height) - Will display a sequence of numbers, and put a nice rectangle underneath them in case you want to easily CSG the sequence of numbers with something else. It's a bit hacky in that the gap between numbers is fixed, and I didn't normalize the polygon data, so it's a fixed size of 38x68. Of course you can scale it, but... Well, there it is. finally off my chest. And now I have nice 7-segment numbers in the bag of tricks. You can guess at the signifance of the number in the picture.

1) Think of some nifty uses for numbers either individually, or in combinations.
2) Download the .scad
3) Enter your number sequence
4) Print
5) Rejoice!

description.text:
My girlfriend just moved into a new flat and her closet has a very high up 2 teir clothes rod to hang clothes. the bottom one she can reach the top one she can't.
I have seen in stores where they have really high up clothes they get a pole with a upside down hook on it to grab the hanger.
I decided to create one to raise the GAF (girlfriend acceptance factor)
I have created one here. This is still a WIP
This will attach to the end of the broomstick. I have created two pieces the main one will fit on the end of the cylinder that i created. This cylinder can be glued one one end. Then slotted on the end of a broom handle. I have created two separate parts because I didn't want to have to print supports for the weirdly shaped item and this cylinder can be scaled to any size broom stick or pole you have and still fit the end of the hanger nicely. I have made it fairly bulky on purpose to support heavy coats I have yet to print this. It will need support on the end of the round section on the hook.

Here are relief maps of Reunion and Mauritius. A GMTED2010 data file, 30s030e_20101117_gmted_mea075.tif, was used to create the maps. The file was was downloaded from earth explorer, http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/ See thing:125606 Martinique and the Caribbees. Two sizes of map are provided. They differ in the scale of the x and y directions, z is unchanged. Stl files are: reunion.stl and reunion_small.stl.
mauritius.stl and mauritius_small.stl The fortran code which made the openSCAD polyhedron commands is included.

The maps can be printed directly on the build platform. Reunion.stl has 320 x 280 points at 7.5 arc-second intervals.
Mauritius.stl has 270 x 340 points at 7.5 arc-second intervals.
The highest point on reunion.stl is 3032 meters; on mauritius.stl 806 meters.

title: Prusa i3 Leadscrew Z axis upgrade

description.text: I am building a HICTOP prusa i3 printer but the z axis wobble a lot, so I decided to get the threaded screws straight https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dy64oB7fG-k but this was not enough, the operation was not smooth. The final solution was to replace the whole z axis with leadscrews and bronze nuts. Besides that, I added some pegs to firmly hold the linear bearings.

author: jbelux

title: Frame profile for supporting LEDs strips around windows.

description.text:
Hi, this is the first of a set of profiles to fix LEDs strips as a window surround. The LEDs can be fitted into any or all of the 3 slots and then fixed in place with hot glue. The middle slot displays the LEDs pointing away from the wall, the left and right are wall and window washers (mini floods).
The first section is the vertical profile that lines the sides. It is designed to be printed in sections and then slides onto 20mm plastic electrical conduit and is hot glued, this way any length can be printed and has a reasonable strength, as a bonus the conduit keeps all the cables neat.
I need to make a few of this profile and then I’ll post the top, bottom and corners.
WIND_TEST2.stl = original upload. UPDATE1: Slightly revised profile - thinner (how uses half the filament and prints twice as fast) - the wall side LEDs have been angled slightly as alot of light wasn't hitting the wall.
WIND_PROF2.stl = revised (1.0mm wall & angled LEDs).
UPDATE2: Have run all the .stl through NetFeb.
Added bracket profile - has a slot 3mm wide, will take a small tiewrap for fixing, 10mm wide gules in as needed.
Added top and bottom profile - this just has the forward facing LED slot.
Added control box in two parts - this control box fits in the top profile and houses the controler board / boards for the frame (if you use the same as me or adapt to suit).
Some photos of part assembled sections.
NEXT UPDATES: Control box lid, corners and photos of fully assembled printed parts.

title: Mercedes Benz Glove Box Key Blank (2006 Style Keys)

description.text:
This is a glove box key blank designed only to fit into the key fob so you can switch the key from one ring to another without having to unwind it from the key ring.  
I couldn't find anyone who tried to do this before so I had to draw it from scratch. It doesn't look exactly like the original but it gets the job done better then expected.

Rotate the key so that the little pin is facing up and the slot is on the build plate.  
I printed this on a MakerBot Replicator (1st Gen) and sanded it down a little to make it look smoother.

UPDATE 2011-10-25
I uploaded shell-012948.stl, the file as exported from Sage, for shell thickening experimentation. It was mirrored from the original exported file because a hermit crab needs a right-handed shell spiral due to the way its abdomen curves. Pimp out your hermit crab! This is the prototype shell for Project Shellter, the current artist residency at MakerBot Industries. It is modeled on the shell of the Cittarium pica sea snail, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cittarium_pica, and is similar to the ones that crabs in pet stores typically sport. It was created using Sage, http://sagemath.org, exported to an STL using a modified version of Christopher Olah's plugin, http://trac.sagemath.org/sage_trac/ticket/7744, and thickened in 3DS Max. You can explore other shell shapes here http://sagenb.org/home/pub/2928 (account required). The goal is a workflow using open source tools, but the conversion of the surface to a solid at this point requires a commercial tool. Maybe someone can figure out a way to thicken the surface without 3DS Maxâ€½ Follow Project Shellter progress here: http://projectshellter.com
http://twitter.com/ProjectShellter
http://bit.ly/ProjectShellter
http://bit.ly/ProjectShellterCams
http://bit.ly/ProjectShellterVideos

This was printed on a Thing-O-Matic with Mk 7 extruder at the world famous BotFarm using Matt's excellent support settings: http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2011/06/27/makerbot-microtip-using-the-support-features-in-skeinforges-raft-tool/ Some notes:
  • It is oriented to eliminate interior support settings; re-orient at your own risk ;)
  • You only need the STL or the zip file; they contain the same thing
  • Once printed, the minimal support material is easily removed and the entire shell is hollow
  • Sanding or tumbling to smooth the surfaces is optional but recommended (more on this later...)
    • You can print it, I know you can! Go! Thanks to @JonMonaghan for the 3DS Max-fu, print and photos (my first print failed, and he kindly reprinted it for me so I didn't miss my flight).

description.text:
For Auto Bed Levelling I have tried a microswitch on a servo, a inductive probe and a capacitive probe. These are the brackets that mount on the extruder fan of a Prusa Research i3 printer. These probes come in 12 and 18mm diameters so there is a bracket for each.
I finally settled on using a capacitive probe part no.LJC18A3-H-Z/BX NPN NC (if you get an NO one you will need to invert the pins on the Z endstop.
The inductive probe part no is: LJ12A3-4-Z/BX NPN NC.

description.text:
Prusa's rod clamps are all well and fine, but I don't actually want to adjust the spacing from Z smooth rod to frame. Here's a one-piece connector with optional bearing holder. Fully parametric, including rod spacing. Match with blddk's derivative of my Integrated Z motor mount+frame vertex+rod clamp - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12215 Overall size of the part comes mostly from washer_diameter and the spacing distances. horiz_distance is the distance between the center of the smooth rod clamp and the threaded rod that goes under the middle of your printer. This can be made smaller (minimum smooth_rod_diameter/2+threaded_rod_diameter/2) if you omit the bearing mount. UPDATED 9 November
uploaded new files with proper distances, preset to the standard, and M8 holes

1) print
2) disassemble half your printer to install

comments.text: I actually find that I get better results if I just leave the threaded rod hanging at the bottom and don't try to anchor it.  That way if the rod isn't entirely straight, it's held by the X end only.  Anchoring it forces any bend to cause the X axis to wobble.

author: Pawel36

description.text:
A 3D model inspired by David Mitchell's beautiful "Electra" origami creation. Ideal for a Christmas tree star or decoration.
Mathgrrl (http://www.thingiverse.com/mathgrrl/about) has kindly added a guest blog on her MakerHome blog showing how this model was created - see http://makerhome.blogspot.co.uk/2014/07/day-327-saturday-guest-auntdaisy-and.html
The model is fairly easy to assemble and can be printed in either a single colour or in five contrasting / complementary colours.
It is based on an icosidodecahedron and consists of 12 pentagonal and 20 triangular rings of modules. Approximately 16.5cm across.
I've included assembly images and photos of both the 3D printed and a paper origami version.
For more information on David Mitchell's origami design, see http://freespace.virgin.net/dave.mitchell/galleriesmodulardesigns.htm or his latest "Paper Crystals" book, http://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0953477495 (with lots of other exciting models.)

Print 5 copies of "Electra_6_mod.STL" - either all the same colour, or in 5 different colours. This will give you a total of 30 modules to slot together.
On our Replicator and using ABS, the print settings were - 10% infill, 0.3 mm layer height, 2 shells, 100mm/s feedrate, 150 mm/s travel, extruder 230 deg C, platform 110 deg C; and no support.
[Note: As a test, the orange pieces were printed with 0% infill and 1 shell; and they worked (but are not as strong as the others).]
Here are the assembly instructions; see "Assembly.JPG".
1) Make a ring of 5 modules - keep the biggest angle inside the ring to make a pentagon. If you're using colours, then these should all be different and in any order you want.
2) On the outside of this ring fit 5 more modules to make 5 triangular rings around the pentagonal ring. The rule for the multi-coloured version is "match the opposite corners of triangles and pentagons" - see "ColourMatch.JPG".
3) You now have 10 modules in a star shape. Add another 10 to complete the next 5 pentagons, i.e. another two to each pentagon. Use the colouring rule, above, to decide on the colour.
4) Nearly done... You now have a hemisphere; add another 5 modules to complete 5 more triangles.
5) Finally, fit 5 modules to make the final 5 triangles and pentagon. You might find it useful to loosen some of the adjacent modules before inserting the last few pieces.
6) Squeeze all the joints together.
7) If the joints are loose, try a bit of glue. I was luckily and there's enough friction to hold the model together.
Good luck and happy assembling.
This model relies on friction (or glue) to keep the joints together. The tightness of the joints will probably depend on the size of your extruder nozzle, print settings and filament. If you have loose joints try scaling down the model, if they're tight scale up...
If you want to be adventurous, you could try one of the other untested STLs - one should give a spherical outer shape, the others add small spheres/points on the vertices.
I've also experimented with locking tabs, but they tended to give surface features on the prints.

The Stripey Electra was printed on a Replicator 1 using filament swapping - 3dfilaprint's Orange PLA 0-62% & 68-78%; Fabadashery's Galaxy Blue PLA 62-68%; 3dfilaprint's Glow-in-the-Dark Blue PLA 78-100% of Replicator print progress. Mainly Makerware PLA defaults, with changes - 1 shell, 7% infill, 205% extruder temperature, 100mm/s extrude. Each set of 6 modules took ~75 minutes to print, and I needed 5 of them (i.e. 30 modules). The model is ~17cm across.

remixed_from.author: elk
remixed_from.title: Transport screw workaround for wade extruder

description.text: You can use this Hobbing Jig to get nice evenly spaced cuts when making a hobbed bolt. I had trouble with some new ABS which had trouble feeding through my extruder. The ABS was a bit thinner (2.7mm) instead of the normal (2.85mm). It was also a lot softer than my imported stock. But because it was locally made, and about half the price of imported ABS, I really wanted it to work. So I set out to make a new hobbolt, which still works in my old extruder, but give better grip. Then I saw this thing by Elk called "Transport screw workaround for wade extruder". (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9291) I tried it, and it works great! But I thought, to get a bit better precision, I need to make a jig. So my Hobbing Jig were born.

Download the OpenSCAD model and change the parameters as needed. You do not need to know OpenSCAD, to use it. It is very strait forward, but for those of you who really only wants a STL, I have included on with a disc diameter of 80mm, divided into 16 divisions for a M8 bolt. (PS: I only learned OpenSCAD today, and boy, am I impressed!)
  • Print the thing.
  • Put a M8 nut in the nut receptor.
  • Tread your M8 bolt through from the bottom.
  • Mark the position on the bolt where you need it to be hobbed.
  • Put it in your drill press. (Do not over tighten as it will damage the threads)
  • Fasten your Dremel-like tool equipped with a small cutting blade to the drill press table.
  • Center the cutting blade on the center of the bolt.
  • Align the cutting blade to the outer edge of the jig, by turning the drill chuck by hand.
  • Switch the dremel on.
  • Swing the drill press table towards the bolt.
  • Make the cut and use the depth adjustment of the drill press to make the cut longer on the bolt.
  • Align to next position and repeat until done.
    • The most difficult part is to fix your dremel-like tool to the drill press table, and to align the blad to the center of the bolt. The nice part of this is if you are doing a few bolts, this needs only to be done once.

author: Fox40

description.text:
The Galapagos sit over a "hot spot" on the earth's crust and have many active volcanos. Here are models of the islands and six volcanos. A very nice introduction to Galapagos geology, which includes descriptions of the individual volcanos, is avaiable at: http://www.geo.cornell.edu/geology/Galapagos.html The models were constructed from NASA's SRTM3 data:
http://dds.cr.usgs.gov/srtm/version2_1/
using a program similar to that described in thing:121275. Stl files are: Galapagos.stl 320 x 280 thirty arc-second intervals
Wolf.stl 200 x 180 three arc-second intervals
Darwin.stl 230 x 230 three arc-second intervals
Alcedo.stl 200 x 220 three arc-second intervals
Sierra_Negra.stl 200 x 200 three arc-second intervals
Cerro_Azul.stl 200 x 200 three arc-second intervals
Fernandina.stl 200 x 200 three arc-second intervals The fortran code that created the polyhedron commands is included.

The models can be printed directly on the build platform.  
Missing SRTM3 data points have the value -32768 and appears as holes in the volcano models. The positions of the holes suggests that the satellite recording the data passed to the east of the Galapagos.  
Scaling is simplified as the Galapagos sit on the equator.  A millimeter on the volcano models equals  230 meters - ( 1 inch is  3.29 miles).  The vertical scale is a mm for every 167 meters.

This is my version of a direct drive extruder. It is optimized for the following aspects:
  • dead simple, no unnecessary parts
  • low profile, maximising effective print height on my prusa
  • easy operation, spring-loaded mechanism for easy load/unload
  • easy to build
    • The source lives at https://github.com/byteborg/mendelparts/tree/master/parts/direct-drive-extruder and you are welcome to play with it. Update version 0.2:
    Added a part to hold the bearing in place (bearing_clip.stl) Update version 0.3:
    Sturdier extruder body Public Service Announcement:
    Print the roller lever in ABS, and print it twice :)
    PLA is too brittle and will break after mangling a few kilograms of material. You want to have one of these in spare.
    Perhaps I'll redesign the lever shape a bit, in case it troubles me too much. Public Service Announcement #2:
    Do use DRV8825 stepper driver for added torque ;-)
BOM

• plastic parts as in STL
  • NEMA17 stepper, as much torque as possible
  • pulley 5mm bore x 8mm outer dia
  • 4x M3x30 screw
  • M3x40 screw
  • spring, fitting said M3 bolt, needs to be strong
  • M3 nylock nut
  • M3 nut
  • 2x M4 nylock nut
  • 9x M3 washer
  • 625ZZ ball bearing
  • 608ZZ ball bearing
  • M8x20mm threaded rod, or 8mm x 20mm smooth rod
  • reprapsource-style hotend (or customize the OpenSCAD file)
  • 2x M3x30 bolts for hotend mount ridges
    • Assembly

• print the parts

    • I made mine from PLA
    • layer 0.3mm thickness, 2 perimeters, 2 solid top/bottom layers, 40% infill

  • roller-lever spring assembly:

    • M3x40 bolt > washer > spring > washer > lever > nylock nut
    • the nylock nut is just threaded flush at the end

  • roller-lever roller assembly

    • put 20mm long piece of 8mm rod through lever and 608ZZ bearing

  • put M4 nylock nuts in nut traps for later mounting on x-carriage

  • attach pulley to motor

    • don't tighten too much, need to adjust later

  • attach NEMA17 motor

    • M3x30 bolt > washer > extruder body > washer > motor
    • put bolts through extruder body, add washers, attach motor

  • attach spring-loaded lever

    • secure with M3 bolt

  • adjust pulley to fit ridge over feed hole

  • press in 625ZZ bearing to side of extruder body

  • install extruder body on x-carriage

  • install hotend to extruder body and secure with bolts
    • Configure firmware. I use 420 steps/mm in Marlin for a RAMPS board with DRV8825 driver in 1/32th microstepping mode. Commissioning

• load filament by pressing down hinged lever

  • adjust spring tension, you'll need lots of it, trust me ;-)

  • print

  • be happy.

comments.text: Looks good, how is the stepper coping with the required torque? I can read things all over the place saying that a geared nema17 is required for a direct drive 3mm
comments.author: thecrazy

comments.text:
I'm using steppers that deliver 43Ncm of torque which appears to be quite enough for printing PLA at around 200°C with a .5mm nozzle. The motor gets quite warm during long prints. I use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22449http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... for cooling with a 40mm 12V Maglev Fan that runs at 5V which appears to be just enough to be nearly inaudible and the stepper stays cool.
The motor runs very slowly while extruding, thus producing higher torque on the motor shaft, compared to geared setups.
The motor drivers go into thermal shutdown, when printing continuously with >60mm/s, thus skipping steps.
I am currently looking into higher power alternatives to the Pololu A4988 drivers. Twin 2A drivers would hit the sweet spot I guess. I am also looking into better cooling options for that.
comments.author: thecrazy

title: E3D direct geared extruder mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It takes time to design and create these things, so if you like it.... the "like" button is not that far away from the download button to show some appreciation ;) For the new Cyrus 3d printer I am going to use the E3D extruder with an geared motor. currently in early phase of testing , I Haven't printed anything with it yet but I don't forsee any problems with it. I would do at least 50% infill, I did 75% for my own. only 3 pieces to print. Pressure is adjusted by simple screw (see cross section render). It is currently in working condition :) tested it myself today work's great for the geared extruder;
http://www.2engineers.com/shop/geared150/ E3d extruder;
http://e3d-online.com/ourshop/ http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UzP2rkEIyc8

Printed with 75% infill,   
I used 1x (3x8x4 bearing which is held in place by an M3x12 socket cap screw).  
The whole part clicks into eachother and is held together tightly by M3 screws. The fan on the picture is the original one which comes when you order the E3D extruder.  
It's quite self explanatory... should you get stuck, let me know!   
Do follow the assembly instruction on their site closely as it prevents headache later!

remixed_from.author: 3DCentralVA
remixed_from.title: Magic The Gathering Mana Deck Boxes

description.text:
NOTE: Development on Thingiverse has stopped. I will be continuing my development on Youmagine. https://www.youmagine.com/designs/customizable-fully-parameterized-magic-card-box The reason i am stopping development is Makerbot (the owner of thingiverse) has begun applying for patents for works done by the opensource printing community. This is theft of intellectual properties. I will leave this file up, but all future developments will be done elsewhere. This card box is designed to allow you to add custom text, and choose a symbol for a box of whatever size you choose. To make it easy the script will calculate the box size depending upon how many cards and what thickness cards you are using.
Note: not ready for customizer, you will have to download and compile it in openScad.

This Model is way out of date, the updated version is on YouMagine Updates include:
More Symbols (phyrexian, multicolor, planeswalker, and a few other)
A new MTG font them based upon the classic MTG font (spacing issues exist)
Completely rewritten to allow for mitered edges, and other furtur projects

this  is  customizable  in  openscad. I  have alot  of  work  to  do  on  this  to  make  it  easy  to  read/ work  in  customize.  but I  wanted  to  get  the  box  out  there  as a  work  in  progress. I  hope  you  enjoy.

author: namomo

description.text:
This is a simple calibration test cube for your 3D printer with X, Y & Z written on the axis. To further calibrate your 3D printer print one out and you can then measure this models dimensions against the expected dimensions. Once this is done you are able, if your 3D printer allows it, to adjust your Steps per mm in your printers firmware. if:
e= expected dimension
o = observed dimension
s = current number of steps per mm then: (e/o) x s = your new number of steps per mm In part though this is the result of a guide on how to make your own 3D printer calibration cube using Freecad ( https://www.idig3dprinting.co.uk/news/how-to-guides/create-a-3d-printer-calibration-cube-in-freecad/ ) So why not have a go at making your own!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 rework

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

30%

Designed using this guide If you want to know how we designed it then please take a look at our post on the subject. All the information is there so that you can design your own ( https://www.idig3dprinting.co.uk/news/how-to-guides/create-a-3d-printer-calibration-cube-in-freecad/ )

comments.text:
Hi to all,
I am new to 3d printing and I have purchased an anet a8 to begin. After 10 days of building, reading, and printing some upgrades like front frame brace, linear bushings for x and y-axis(originals was like they have gravel inside from the noise), and belt tensioners (for both x and z-axis), and some 3d models for fun, I decided to print this test cube to see what happens. comments.text: Looks great. You do have some "ghosting" beside the "X" and "Y" letters. This is caused by the print head oscillating after a sharp move. description.text: This is a differential cyclodial gearbox which achieves a large ratio by a similar mechanism to the "split planetary" gearbox, but with far fewer and much less delicate parts. With this large a gear reduction ratio, small & light "tin can" or "pancake" stepper motors, usually considered useless, may be useful for things like extruders. This one is designed to fit a PF-35T-48L4 motor I got from salvage. (Very similar one on sparkfun https://www.sparkfun.com/products/10551 ) Sources available on my personal site: http://burningsmell.org/3d/hypo35/

I did not want to put four little, fragile pins on the inside of the gear as pictured in most cycloidal solutions. It is designed so that the output is co-axial with the input, letting everything load-bearing easily sit on ball bearings. It requires a few vitamins.
1 X 625 ball-bearing.
2 X 12mm M3 screws and 2x M3 nuts to attach the input motor.
1 X M5 hex-head screw to fit in the output gear.
4 X 25mm M3 screws and nuts to attach the output to anything willing to attach to a NEMA17 I used a center pin machined from metal instead of a printed one. The main difficulty with a printed one is fixing it solidly to a round shaft, something like krazy glue may be needed.

The offset pin, dark blue, is attached solidly to the motor shaft but is free to spin in the 625 bearing(violet).  This forces the light blue gear to "roll" around the inside.  Since it is only 1 tooth fewer than the outside, it rotates once per 12 rotations.
It fits into the output gear (not shown) with a different ratio, 1 in 11.  Since the ratio differs, the output gear is forced to rotate to make up the difference.  This speed is the difference between the ratios, so becomes very small.

comments.author: robodurden

comments.text: 60*144 RPM input, or 8640RPM, is well into dremel territory -- a tin can stepper has no hope.  It's rated for 1800 revolutions per minute, unloaded, absolute theoretical max, and I suspect that's a stretch.
comments.author: robodurden

comments.text:
I power my bike with a multipole brushless RC helicopter motor. And they are more expensive than a Nema17.
The PM35S-048-XTC5 stepper (google for images) at 24V is shown with a max of 1000 PPS (pulses per seconds) which is only 1000 / 360 x 7.5 x 60 = 1250 rpm
For a 10:1 ratio i would use a single stag planetary gear.
Up to 30:1 i would choose a split planetary gearbox: http://www.zakgear.com/Split_Gear.html
A Nema14 can go up to 5000 pps which would yield 6250 rpm. http://www.alltronics.com/mas_assets/acrobat/14HR08.pdf
But that would not make the steppers cheaper nor a big weight reduction.
comments.author: Corona688

comments.text: A stepper is going to have next to no power at those speeds, is the problem.  That's why I suggested a multipole motor - they're actually intended to deliver force at those speeds.
comments.author: robodurden

comments.text: Hypocycloids often don't work in reverse because the line of force is the wrong direction half the time, not because of some supposed massive inefficiency.  Internally they roll, not slide.  A hyperbolic worm gear on the other hand is going to have wear out the wazoo.  Worms are among the least efficient gear reduction systems.
comments.author: robodurden

comments.text:
Now i got it, this is nothing but a split/differential planetary gear with only 1 planet and no suns: https://youtu.be/C8d6fEVcT5c
And so the output only has contact to one tooth and the high resolution of a 144:1 ratio gets lost :-(
comments.author: robodurden

comments.text: Stepper motors have near-zero torque at that speed.  That's how fast they can freewheel, not how fast they can push.
comments.author: robodurden

author: jeremymoulton

title: Extruder gears set for Techzone Huxley extruder.

description.text:
This is an extruder gears set for the TechZone Huxley extruder, featuring herringbone teeth. It is intended to replace the 2 lasercut wooden gears. I printed one set but haven't mounted it yet - I'm waiting for the original gears to break or wear first. This use 2 modules from the MCAD library that you can get from https://github.com/elmom/MCAD - Thanks to the authors.
Some bits - the motor gear mount hub with set screw hole - are derived from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3104 (thanks GilesBathgate) which is under GPL CC license.

Print, mount, recalibrate your E_STEPS_PER_MM (ratio changed), use and let me know how it works.
I suggest printing those separately - hence the 2 STLs - if your printer oozes / strings.

This is purita's model, with a hole added in the belly area to allow mounting it onto the included base.
Single-extruder printer users will want to rotate the horse onto its hind/tail end, about 70 degrees off of the horizontal, to minimize the impact from the support material.
Make sure the support columns are SOLIDLY fixed to the plate so that the vibrations from the movements of the table don't knock them over. Slic3r produces a few pretty thin ones with this model, but a raft and brim should help that issue.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes: I recommend printing the stand separately from the horse (in my case, the movements of the head, variations in nozzle flow, etc. caused the stand to develop weak spots during print that were not repeated when I re-printed it alone). Careful of the front hooves, they're a little weak around the ankles.

I just loaded the model into Blender, generated the stand object from two cylinders and a bit of resizing, then used the upper end of the thin one to punch a hole into the horse model, which I then expanded a bit to provide a decent gap (you may still need to ream it out, or sand the top of the stand down a bit)

author: Baptiste_mse

description.text: This is a multi function manipulative color sorter that works on both color pairing as well as small muscles in the fingers and hands. The person sorts the colored chips into the hive that matches in color. This can also be used by occupational therapists either as is or with the use of tweezers to increase fine motor skills.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black
I designed this with little fingers and minds in mind. Adding grips to the chips allowed for a better grasp as well as the ability to use tweezers if one chooses to do so.

Project: Bee Hive Color Sorter Objectives: Students will learn how to pair colors. An added feature is improving fine motor skills while doing so. Audiences: Audiences: This is good for Preschool as well as early intervention, special needs children and Alzheimer's or Stroke patients. Preparation: Preparation: Students should be old enough or know not to put items in their mouth to use this manipulative. Tweezers or Tongs can be used to increase fine motor skill if desired. Results At the end of this project you will have made a sorting system with as many sorters and coins as you desire. Each set should be printed in a different color with as many colors as you deem necessary. After placing the sorters in front of your student, hand him or her a coin and instruct the student to sort the coin. You can increase how many coins are given at once until the student has mastered all colors.
